ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Egyptian history and how other countries interpreted and interacted with it.
I personally was able to learn about the origins of a lot of motifs and inspirations for much of the worlds architecture, art, religions, philosophy, and actions.
I developed a lot of useful insight into Egyptian art and culture.

I learned a lot about how to look at the synthesis of multiple eras and cultures as it applies to an object. It made me a better art historian, more aware of cultural connections and better prepared to approach detailed discussion thereof.
I learned a ton about ancient Egypt and how it affects and has affected cultural practices across geographic and temporal locations around the world.
Egyptianizing artworks, architecture, literature, and religious, intellectual practices throughout history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths - very interesting, great professor, worthwhile classes Weaknesses - a lot of outside work for class, meaning having to go to museums, libraries etc. Though not a huge hinderance, but a lone weakness.

The class covers a very interesting but broad topic - it looks as the appropriation of Egyptian motifs and ideas from prehistory to present. Due to the breadth of the time period, the class is more introductory than I thought, but the topic and discussions are really interesting!
I liked all the independent work we got to do in this course.
Really can't think of any weaknesses. Strength is definitely in the lectures, they were super engaging.
The major themes in the class are very interesting, and the trips to the Beinecke and the Center for British Art were fun. The lectures, however, could be more structured and more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend, the class material is very interesting.

Yes, I think courses like this that examine and provide examples of the origins of so many contemporary designs and such should be required among art history classes and the like. Also just in general a very interesting subject to learn about.
Yes it was a very enjoyable course.
Yes! Cool subject matter, short assignments, awesome professor.
Yes!!! Professor Darnell is amazing and the course is so fun and interesting. I had never taken a class in Egyptian art before and I'm so glad that I was able to my last semester. I loved it.
Yes, if you are interested in Egypt, this is a good course to engage with some of the major themes of Egypt's afterlife.
